newsitem.title: USA: Hewlett-Packard in pacts with Oracle.
newsitem.headline: Hewlett-Packard in pacts with Oracle.

text.p: Hewlett-Packard Co chief executive officer Lewis Platt said HP won't take sides in the escalating industry war over the merits of the personal computer versus the network computer.

Despite being a keynote speaker at an Oracle Corp conference devoted to network computing -- Oracle's idea of inexpensive NCs that don't process applications but are linked via intranets to servers that hold the applications and databases -- Platt did not endorse the NC and told reporters HP won't be making NCs.
The system can hold 1.3 terabytes of data. A terabyte is 1,000 gigabytes or one million megabytes.

That is a huge amount of data -- such as might need to be stored by a retailer trying to do electronic commerce by maintaining a database of merchandise inventory, prices and a record of sales transactions.

Datawarehousing means systems for storing and organizing huge amounts of data and software, which enable the user to retrieve that data by various means for analysis and to help make corporate decisions on marketing, reengineering and other subjects.
In a second pact, HP has agreed to resell Oracle's existing database, Oracle 7, with its OpenView network management product, Platt said.

He said that OpenView is one of HP's answers to the problem many corporations have in managing the complexity of in-house networks. That same problem is one of the things Oracle is trying to address with its network computer.
